channel.title: Essays on MillMint
channel.description: Recent content in Essays on MillMint

item.title: A Universal Nostalgia
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } A Universal Nostalgia: Spatiality Across Studio Ghibli V ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This thesis was completed in partial fulfillment of Honours in a Bachelor of Media. It remains a good testament to my love of Ghibli.

item.title: Utopie Concrète
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } Utopie Concrète K ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This essay was written in June 2021. Click here to see it as a post. A New Style of Utopia # I write introspectively about the project sometimes, as a means by which I consider what I’m doing and where my unconscious is leading me with this project.

item.title: Landscapes of Waugh
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } Landscape in the Age of Frustration ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This article was originally published in October 2019. It offers an analysis of Evelyn Waugh’s Handful of Dust through an anti-utopian prism.

item.title: Not Long in Hong Kong
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } Not Long in Hong Kong « ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This article was originally published in October 2019. This article was written shortly after my return from Hong Kong, where I got caught up in the pro-democracy protests and is a broad response to Australian coverage of the ongoing events.

item.title: Why Money?
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } Why Money? $ ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This essay was written for Patrons in February 2021. W hy money? Perhaps better inverted here: why have money at all?

item.title: A Cashless Tokyo
item.description: .markdown a { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a.anchor { color: var(--color-blue); } aside nav ul a { color: var(--color-blue); } #headerbox .emoji { color: var(--color-blue); } .markdown a:visited { color: var(--color-blue); } A Cashless Tokyo 9 ESSAY Newsdesk ❖ Note from the Editor This article was originally published in December 2018. Yes, it’s painfully self-concerned and a little difficult to read back, but for newcomers to the project you might find some “obvious truths” about Vekllei you have not yet encountered.
